result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

charges.descr: Battery to a Law Enforcement Officer

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Jesus D. Rodriguez

records.addlTxt:
(3:08 PM case called.) Prosecuting attorney Trenton Piltz in court for the State of Wisconsin. Defendant Jesus D. Rodriguez does not appear in court or via Zoom. Attorney Robert Allen Thorson in court for Jesus D. Rodriguez.
Attorney Thorson advises was just appointed on April 27, 2022 and sent a letter to the defendant with today's date and time and asking for the defendant to contact Attorney Thorson. Attorney Thorson does not have a phone number for the defendant and hasn't heard from the defendant.
Court notes the defendant was given this date in court.
State advises was ready to proceed, witness is present and requests a warrant.
Court orders warrant.

records.descr: Demand for Discovery and Inspection - Defendant

records.addlTxt:

11:18 AM case called. Prosecuting attorney Kelly Ronquist in court for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant Jesus D. Rodriguez appeared by video, in custody with Attorney Karl Schmidt. 
Defense waives reading of the complaint. A preliminary hearing is scheduled for 5-10-22 at 2:30 PM.

Conditions:
No contact with Officer Madrid.
No acts or threats of violence against anyone.
